Award.AwardTitle: High Resolution Thermal Expansion Measurements of Ice
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
This project is concerned with high-resolution measurements of the thermal expansion of single-crystalline ice at atmospheric pressure. The measurements will provide up to 10,000 times higher relative resolution than previous measurements, yielding new information about the anisotropy of the thermal expansion and the first structural investigation of a poorly understood phase transition at 115 K. Improved knowledge of ice's thermal expansion will impact cold-region engineering, climate modeling, the study of Earth's polar regions, astrophysics, and our basic understanding of the motion of hydrogen atoms in ice and their role in determining its physical properties. New temperature sensor technology resulting from this project will increase the relative resolution of temperature measurements by a factor of 100; this will improve determination of the thermal expansion coefficient, but may have other applications. A compact thermal expansion cell will be constructed of single-crystalline sapphire to facilitate measurements in the range 0.35 K to 20 K. Undergraduates will be responsible for a large portion of this project. They will fabricate experimental equipment, grow and orient single crystals, test and calibrate highly sensitive devices and learn fundamental physics associated with solids.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Water is arguably the most important substance on our planet. In its solid form, known as ice, it is highly complex. Depending on the pressure, it can assume thirteen distinct crystal structures. The most predominant on Earth is the structure known as ice Ih, which exists at atmospheric pressure. Surprisingly, its expansion under changes in temperature (thermal expansion) has never been measured to very high resolution. This project will produce thermal expansion data with a relative resolution about 10,000 times better than prior measurements. Improved knowledge of the thermal expansion of ice will impact cold- region engineering, climate modeling, the study of Earth's polar regions, and astrophysics. It will also improve our understanding of the motion and low-temperature freezing of hydrogen atoms, and their role in determining the crystal structure and properties of ice. This project will produce significant improvements in the measurement of temperature, increasing the relative resolution by a factor of 100. Advances in measuring the thermal expansion at temperatures close to absolute zero are also expected. Undergraduate students will be responsible for a large portion of this research. They will fabricate experimental equipment, grow and orient single crystals, test and calibrate highly sensitive devices and learn fundamental physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water is nature’s most important material. Without it, life would not exist. Water is highly complex, with the ability to dissolve many solids and bind to molecules that are important to all biological systems. The solid form of water is known as ice. It is equally complex, with the ability to form 14 known crystal structures, most of which exist at high pressure. The crystal structure on the surface of earth is hexagonal and known as H2O ice Ih. It has been studied using many experimental techniques through the decades. The thermal expansion of H2O ice Ih has never been measured with high resolution. The purpose of this project was to fill this gap. Single crystal of ice were grown so that the length change of H2O ice Ih could be measured along its two crystallographic directions aand c. The relative resolution of the experiments was one part in one billion, which is at least 4000 times higher relative resolution than any past experiments. Single crystals of D2O ice Ih were also grown and measured. D2O is known as “heavy water” since the D atom, deuterium, has one neutron and one proton unlike hydrogen, which has only one proton. The additional mass of D influences the physical properties of ice in a way that can aid in interpreting data. 

 

Our data is shown in the attached figure. The results reveal:

1. Differences, referred to as anisotropy, in the thermal expansion between the crystallographic aand caxes were observed for the first time.

2. Below 60 K ice expands upon cooling, an unusual behavior. This was measured with unprecedented precision and its shift in D2O was observed for the first time. Our analysis shows that this feature is associated with vibrations of entire H2O (or D2O) molecules. 

3. An extremely large phase transition was observed in H2O ice at 101 K with a structural probe for the first time. The feature is at 125 K in D2O, a dramatic upward shift. 

4. The phase transition was attributed to Intrinsic-Localized Modes (ILMs). These are local vibrating regions in the crystal, that do not couple well to neighboring vibrating regions. The poor coupling is associated with defects that are present in ice Ih. Another name for ILMs is lattice solitons. 

5. A possible lattice soliton was identified. It corresponds to the rotation of H2O molecules. Using a theory for lattice solitons in ice-like structures, the dramatic shift of the transition temperature from 101 K in H2O to 125 K in H2O was explained. 

 

One of the most basic and important broad outcomes of this work is the availability of high-resolution data describing how H2O ice Ih expands upon warming. These data can be used for future applications in engineering and science. The intellectual merit of this project is how it will affect the thinking of scientists surrounding this important solid. Our results suggest that above 101 K the H2O molecules in ice Ihare dynamic. They rotate about their crystallographic positions in a manner that is similar to how they behave in the liquid state. However, they do not move laterally from their positions, as they would in the liquid state. Thus, H2O seems to enter a true solid state, as scientists think of a solid, below 101 K.
